Media notes: Calls from an adult after pishing.

Observation Details: Tan stripe with flock of WCSP

Media notes: In a tree calling. Elevation: 22 m. Date added to IBC: June 22, 2016.
Calls from an adult foraging and then perched low in firs along the edge of the open area at the summit.
Chip calls made at dusk from their roost site in an evergreen tree in my yard.

Observation Details:
Continuing. Originally found by Mike San Miguel 10/26. North end of riparian strip with WCSP, SOSP, and DEJU. Later seen along creek behind Firepit, where it was more vocal.
 
 UPDATE: Changed count to 2.  At the time, I had the feeling I photographed 2 different birds based on location and differences in behavior, but couldn't confirm. I couldn't find any striking plumage differences in the photos while checking camera in field. Recently, other observers confirmed 2 birds seen at the same time. Looking at the photos again on the computer, there does seem to be some subtle differences in eye line shape toward the rear and the color of supercillium (if it's not a lighting artifact)

Background Species: Cyanocitta cristata -- Blue Jay; Dumetella carolinensis -- Gray Catbird; Corvus brachyrhynchos -- American Crow

Media notes: Behavior and other notes: Adult male White-throated Sparrow (tan form) giving calls from a brush pile. Recorder HPF on at 80 Hz, -12 dB/octave. Channels: Mono. Distance to source: 7 meters. Recording Time: 0701 (UTC -5). Temperature 3.9°C. Habitat: Eastern Deciduous Forest. Specific location: Wood Song, 1.5 km WSW of Johnsontown, Berkeley Co., West Virginia. Latitude: 39.575464, Longitude: -78.056623, Elevation: 156 meters. ID’d by: Sight and sound 100%. Playback: No. Recordist original file name: WH_24T0007_White-throated Sparrow male calls_Berkeley Co WV.wav

Two in a dense spruce tree surrounded by open space (weedy meadows, pond). One continuously calling. A second flitting (wingbeats heard) and  calling infrequently at first; more later. Just a meter or two from the path; started calling as I walked by in the dusk.
Observation Details: Calling from a spruce tree as I walked by. I heard a second bird moving around in the tree. Its call shows up later in the recording. The recording of the barred owl also has WTSP in the background--I could not hear it/them, but it is clear on the spectrogram. At the time I was about 300' from the spruce tree, and closer to dense willows. I'm assuming these recordings are of the same birds.

Media notes: 2 birds giving flight calls from a tree near M.A.S.T
